subject: Re: [junit] How to Test Private Methods Inside a Class
msgSnippet: ... I m not sure you are going against me. I don t like reflection either. My continued belief is that classes should be tested through their public
messageBody:
Stephen Smith wrote:
> Much as I dislike going against Elliotte, I'm going to stick to my guns.

I'm not sure you are going against me. I don't like reflection either.
My continued belief is that classes should be tested through their
public interfaces. I've elucidated the reasons here in the past. Rather
than reiterating them here, perhaps it's time to write up something a
little more formal on my blog so I can just point to it in the future.

> I like reflection, but after bingeing on it when I was young and foolish
> I now tend to avoid it. I'm uncomfortable using reflection and fiddling
> with run-time modifiers solely for the purposes of calling a private
> method from a test case.

I completely agree.

> As I originally stated (and elaborated upon by Joakim), I would suggest
> instead analysing exactly _why_ the private method needs testing. If it
> is sufficiently important to require a test case, does its functionality
> merit a change in access modifier? Is its behaviour sufficiently
> different to that of the parent class that an extraction to a public
> helper class might be possible?
>

If the behavior is general enough that you want it to be public *for
reasons other than testing* then by all means, go ahead and make it
public. But don't let the tail wag the dog. If the only reason you want
it public is for testing, then use the public interface instead.
